chapter.title: Default Installation Scenarios
chapter.para: After planning the installation with downloading the software and checking the minimal hardware requirements, there are three default installation scenarios:

sect1.title: Planning the Installation
sect1.para: Plan the installation with downloading the software and checking the minimal hardware requirements.

step.para: Download the DVD ISO image of &sles4sapreg; 11 (electronic media kit).
Burn the image onto a physical DVD and ensure that it is bootable. Alternatively, you might use a virtual CD-ROM device for installation into a virtual machine.

listitem.para: For the Installation with Wizard, at least 60 GB hard disk space for the system volume and 200 GB for the data partition are required.

sect1.title: Booting the Installation Medium
sect1.para: Different scenarios are available to install &sles4sap; 11. Select the preferred installation scenario from the DVD boot menu:

listitem.para: Booting the system installed on the local hard disk.
A standard SLES installation prepared for installing SAP applications later. You can install SAP applications with 3rd party installation routines.
This scenario is suitable for experienced administrators who want to install &sles4sap; according to their own plan. The default package selection is already adapted to SAP installations.

varlistentry.term: SLES for SAP Applications — Installation with Wizard (see )

listitem.para: This is a guided installation of the operating system and a SAP application. After the installation of the operating system the SAP Installation Wizard will start for installation of a validated SAP solution.

varlistentry.term: SLES for SAP Applications — Installation with External Profile (see )

listitem.para: This installation is driven by a user-provided &ay; profile. There are no &suse;-provided SAP optimizations.
This scenario is suitable for experienced users who are familiar with &ay; and want to deploy their own &ay; profiles to install &sles4sap;.
Starting a minimal Linux system without a graphical user interface. For more information, see the &admin;, Chapter 34, Common Problems and Their Solutions; find the &admin; at .
Testing the system RAM using repeated read and write cycles. For more information, see the &admin; Chapter 34, Common Problems and Their Solutions.

sect1.para:
The first part is a standard manual &sls; installation; for details about such a SLES installation, see the SLES &deploy;, Chapter 6, Installation with &yast;.
In addition, the SAP Application Server Base (sap-loc and sapconf) pattern will be installed by default and basic settings will be configured.
You will be prompted for all common installation settings, like partitioning of storage devices, network, or software packages.

title.guimenu: SLES for SAP Applications — Installation with Wizard

sect1.para: This is a guided installation of the operating system with optimized settings for SAP applications.
During this installation scenario, the following installation and configuration steps will take place and interactive settings are required or possible.

sect2.title: Data Required for Installing the System (with Wizard)
sect2.para: The following data is required for the &sls; part of the installation (required per physical server):

entry.para: Master password for the system installation (root password)

sect2.para: The following data is required for the SAP part of the installation (required per SAP system):

entry.para: SAP System ID of the system to be built up
Virtual IP address for SAP service (*)
Instance number of the SAP system
Solution Manager key for the SAP system (*)
System T-Shirt Sizing (S, M, L, or customer-specific size) (*)

sect2.para: (*) not required for TREX.

sect2.title: Selecting SLES for SAP Applications — Installation with Wizard from the DVD Boot Menu
sect2.para: From the DVD boot menu (see ), select SLES for SAP Applications — Installation with Wizard. The installation process loads and configures a Linux system with all requirements for a SAP installation. To view the boot messages and copyright notices during this process, press Esc. On completion of this process, the &yast; installation program starts and displays the graphical installer, which will run mostly automatically.

sect2.title: Preparing System for Automated Installation
sect2.para: After analyzing your computer, the next &yast; pop-up dialog will let you specify the volume configuration. Here you configure the volume for the system and swap space. The data volume comes later, after you select the SAP Application.
If there is just one hard disk, keep it as the system volume device and set the size of the system volume (and the swap space) in GB in the lower field and confirm it; see .

tip.title: Size of the System Volume
tip.para: At least 60 GB is required for the system volume. The swap space depends on the available main memory (RAM). For more information, see the SAP Note 1597355: .

sect2.para: If there is more than one hard disk, select the right one as the system volume device and set the size of the system volume (and the swap space) in GB in the lower fields and confirm it.

warning.title: Deleting Data
warning.para: If you confirm the storage volume configuration, all existing data on the hard disk will be deleted. If you do not want this to happen, turn off the system.

sect2.para: After confirmation, &yast; performs the software installation. Packages are installed one by one, so you can see the progress.

sect2.title: Password for the System Administrator &rootuser;
sect2.para: When all packages are installed, the basic installation is finished, and the system is rebooted for initial configuration, you will be prompted to enter a Password for the System Administrator &rootuser;; see .

&rootuser; is the name of the superuser, or the administrator of the system. Unlike regular users (who may or may not have permission to access certain areas or execute certain commands on the system), &rootuser; has unlimited access to change the system configuration, install programs, and set up new hardware. The &rootuser; account should only be used for system administration, maintenance, and repair. Logging in as &rootuser; for daily work is rather risky: a single mistake could lead to irretrievable loss of system files.
For verification purposes, the password for &rootuser; must be entered twice. Do not forget the &rootuser; password. Once entered, this password cannot be retrieved.
The &rootuser; password can be changed any time later in the installed system. To do so, run &yast; and start Security and Users User and Group Management .

warning.title: The root User
warning.para: The &rootuser; user has all the permissions needed to make changes to the system. To carry out such tasks, the &rootuser; password is required. You cannot carry out any administrative tasks without this password.

sect2.title: Hostname, Domain Name, and IP Address
sect2.para: The next dialog starts with the network configuration; see .

figure.title: Hostname, Domain Name, and IP Address

sect2.para: The Hostname is the computer’s name in the network. The Domain Name is the name of the network. A hostname and domain are proposed by default. If your system is part of a network, the hostname has to be unique in this network, whereas the domain name has to be common to all hosts on the network.
Also enter the IP Address and Netmask for this host. The IP address must be unique and the netmask has to be common to all hosts on the network.

sect2.title: Domain Name Service (DNS) and Time Server (NTP)
sect2.para: The next dialog continues with the network configuration; see .

figure.title: Domain Name Service (DNS) and Time Server (NTP)

sect2.para: For Domain Name Service (DNS) configuration, enter the Domain Searchlist and the IP Address of DNS Server plus the IP address of the Default Gateway of your network.
Also enter the address of the NTP Server to synchronize automatically via Network Time Protocol (NTP).

sect2.title: Registration
sect2.para: To get technical support and product updates, you need to register and activate your product with the &ncc;; see . This dialog provides assistance for doing so. Find detailed information about &ncc; at .

Enter your E-Mail Address and Registration Code for the product. If you provide the registration code now, operating system updates will be installed automatically during the installation of the system.

sect2.title: System Configuration Settings
sect2.para: After confirming the registration data, the system will be configured with the supplied settings.
No user action is required at this stage.

warning.title: Firewall Disabled
warning.para: This wizard-based installation scenario disables the firewall (SuSEfirewall2) completely.

If needed, you can activate the firewall after the installation. If you activate the firewall after the installation, you must open all required ports manually. For more information about required ports, see .

sect2.title: SAP Product Installation
sect2.para: After applying the configuration settings, you are prompted to continue with the SAP Product Installation using the SAP Installation Wizard. The SAP Installation Wizard will install the SAP application from the SAP media kits you received from SAP.

tip.title: SAP Product Installation Default Settings
tip.para: SAP Product Installation default settings are specified and documented in /etc/sysconfig/sap-installation-wizard. You can change them according to your needs.

sect2.para: Confirm the pop-up (see ), if you want to continue with the installation right away. On the other hand, it is possible to interrupt the installation process at this point and resume it after a system restart.

tip.title: Resuming SAP Installation after System Restart
tip.para: To resume the SAP installation with the wizard, start &yast; and select the SAP Product Installer (Computer, then in the YaST Control Center click MiscellaneousSAP Product Installer; see ). The functionality is the same, but the layout of the dialogs is different; the left progress pane is only displayed when continuing with the installation without a restart.
The following screen shots document the installation with the SAP Product Installer that runs after a restart of the system.

sect2.para: In the next dialog provide the Location of the SAP Installation Master; see . The location could be a local source (directory (dir://), locally connected hard disk (device://), USB mass storage (usb://), or CD-ROM (cdrom://)), or a remotely provided installation source (either NFS (nfs://) or SMB (smb://))—select the corresponding option from the pull-down list on the left.

tip.title: Remote Location Specification
tip.para: Peter V. is asked to provide info about SMB and ISO. If you want to install from an NFS source, you must enter the name of the server and the complete path to the media data.

sect2.para: For more information about setting up a remote installation server, see the &sls; 11 &deploy;, Section 14.2, Setting Up the Server Holding the Installation Sources (the &deploy; comes with the product or is available from ).

To save time and space, you can also loop mount ISO images on the installation server. For more information, see the &sls; 11 &deploy;, Section 14.2.6, Using ISO Images of the Installation Media on the Server.

figure.title: SAP Installation Wizard: SAP Installation Master Location

sect2.para: In the next dialog you can select the SAP products you want to install. The offerings of available products depend on the media-set and installation master you received from SAP; for example, see .

For example, select the Enhancement Package 5 for SAP ERP and click Next. Now the relevant part of the SAP media will be copied to the hard drive of the machine for the following SAP installation (after copying, see the contents of /data/SAP_CDs; the layout is explained later in this chapter). This is repeated for all necessary SAP medias, with some additional simple questions.
After copying the Installation Master Media, as step 2 enter the location of the database medium (e.g., the SAP MaxDB RDBMS); see for an NFS installation example.

figure.title: SAP Installation: Location of the Database Medium

sect2.para: Now you must provide the medium with the application server framework. As step 3 you are asked for the Path to a Kernel or Java Medium. For example, if you want to install an ABAP based system, provide the SAP Kernel for NW70 EHP1 Linux; see for an NFS installation example.

figure.title: SAP Installation: Path to a Kernel or Java Medium

sect2.para: As step 4 for the Type of Installation, select Central Installation; see .
As step 5 enter the location of the Export Media (e.g., the SAP CRM Installation Export DVD); see for an NFS installation example.

figure.title: SAP Installation: Location of the Export Media

sect2.para: If needed, add the additional export media, when installation wizard asks about it.

Then you can then copy a CryptoAddOn medium; this is optional. Generally, the encryption feature depends on the SAP product.
Starting with SAP NetWeaver 7.03/7.3 the cryptographic functionality is already included in the SAP NetWeaver DVDs and does not have to be specified separately. In case the wizard will ask you to insert the medium containing the cryptographic functionality, consult the on how to receive the encryption files.
At this point, all required data for the SAP installation are selected and copied to /data/SAP_CDs/0, one directory per medium:

sect2.para: /data/SAP_CDs is the default as specified in the /etc/sysconfig/sap-installation-wizard configuration file.
In the following configuration dialogs enter the details for the SAP installation.

In , as SID (SAP System ID) enter the three letter SAP System ID such as ERP. Enter the SAP Instance Number. Enter and repeat the SAP Master Password that must fulfill the requirements described in the help text. Finally specify the System T-Shirt-Sizing. The SAP SCS Instance Number is only required for Java installations. For details, see the online help on the left.
In , enter the virtual network settings, if needed.
In , select the the database log mode, and—if needed—install the SAP Cryptographic Library. Provide the location of the Crypto Add-On medium, if the wizard asks for it.
At this stage it is possible to install the Supplement Medium; see . For more information about the Supplement Media, see .

Now all installation data (media and settings) are available to the wizard, and the final deployment of the SAP system can take place with the SAP installer (SAPinst). The SAP installer visualizes the installation steps it performs; see .

note.title: Installation Progress
note.para: Depending on your machine it takes a while until the SAPinst tool shows up.

sect2.para: After the SAP installer has finished, you will see a short summary of the installation data.

title.guimenu: SLES for SAP Applications — Installation with External Profile

sect1.para: This installation is driven by a user-provided &ay; profile and there is no wizard support. This scenario is suitable for experienced users who are familiar with &ay; and want to deploy their own &ay; profiles to install &sles4sap;. For more information about &ay; profiles, see the SLES &ay; Guide (the &ay; Guide comes with the product or is available from ).

In order to use a user-provided &ay; profile, select Install SLES for SAP Applications — Installation with External Profile from the DVD Boot Menu. Within the boot options, change the autoyast=usb:/// parameter to the location of a user-provided &ay; profile, or enter the location when &yast; asks for it in the next dialog.

You can also reference the SAP specific pattern, the HA and WebYaST components and SAP-specific IBM Java in your &ay; profile and then install it during this installation scenario. As everything else, these components are not preselected and you must include this yourself in your autoyast.xml file.

sect2.title: About &ay;
sect2.para: &ay; is a system for installing one or more SUSE Linux systems automatically and without user intervention. &ay; installations are performed using an &ay; profile with installation and configuration data. That profile can be created using the &ay; configuration interface and can be provided to &yast; during installation in different ways.
